Ezra 8, beginning in verse number 21
because we had spoken unto the king saying, the hand of our God is upon all them for good that seek him, but his power and his wrath is against all them that forsake him.
So we fasted and besought our God for this. That's prayer. Prayer and fasting. And I want you to notice the end of verse 23, it says, and he was entreated of us.

But we find here in Ezra chapter 8 an illustration how that people, that they seek the face of God and in the midst of a serious situation, they determine that they're not going to rely on the resources that might be available to them through some other means, but they're going to trust the Lord.

The Bible says in verse number 1 of Ezra 9, Now when these things were done, the princes came to me, saying, The people of Israel and the priests and the Levites have not separated themselves from the people of the lands, doing according to their abominations, even of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Jebusites, the Ammonites, the Moabites, the Egyptians, and the Amorites.

For they have taken up their daughters for themselves and for their sons, so that the holy seed have mingled themselves with the people of those lands. Yea, the hand of the princes and rulers hath been chief in this trespass.
And when I heard this thing, I rent my garment and my mantle, and plucked off the hair of my head and of my beard, and sat down a stone-eyed.

Then were assembled unto me every one that trembled at the words of the God of Israel, because of the transgression of those that had been carried away, and I sat a stone-eyed until the evening sacrifice.
And at the evening sacrifice I arose up from my heaviness, and having rent my garment and my mantle, I fell upon my knees, and spread out my hands unto the Lord my God,
O my God, I am ashamed and blush to lift up my face to thee, my God, for our iniquities are increased over our head, and our trespass is grown up unto the heavens.
lifting up our face to the Lord and saying, our iniquities are increased over our head.

since the days of our fathers have we been in great trespass unto this day. And for our iniquities have we, our kings and our priests, been delivered into the hand of the kings of the lands, to the sword, to captivity, to a spoil, to confusion of face as it is this day.
Now for a little space, grace hath been showed from the Lord our God to leave us a remnant
to escape and to give us a nail in His holy place, that our God may lighten our eyes and give us a little reviving in our bondage.

The Bible says in Ezra 7, in verse number 1, now after these things, in the reign of Artaxerxes, king of Persia, Ezra, the son of Sariah, the son of Azariah, the son of Hilkiah, the son of Shalom, the son of Zadok, the son of Ahitab, the son of Amoriah, the son of Azariah, the son of Merioth, the son of Zerahiah, the son of Uzziah, the son of Bukkiah, the son of Abishua, the son of Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, the chief priest.

This Ezra, notice in verse number 6, went up from Babylon and he was a ready scribe in the law of Moses, which the Lord God of Israel had given, and the king granted him all his requests according to the hand of the Lord his God upon him.

Verse number 7, and there went up some of the children of Israel, and of the priests and the Levites and the singers and the porters and the Nethanims unto Jerusalem in the seventh year of Artaxerxes the king.
For upon the first day of the first month began he to go up from Babylon, and on the first day of the fifth month came he to Jerusalem according to the good hand of his God upon him.
For Ezra had prepared his heart to seek the law of the Lord and to do it and to teach in Israel statutes and judgments.
His genealogy is described in verses 1 through 5, and we find that it's traced back to Aaron the chief priest.
And we begin to get into verses 6 through 9, and we begin to understand kind of some of the circumstances in which Ezra was serving the Lord.

In Ezra eight, in verse 31, the Bible says this, 'Then we departed from the river of Ahava on the twelfth day of the first month to go
blessed be the Lord God of our fathers, which hath put such a thing as this in the king's heart to beautify the house of the Lord, which is in Jerusalem
and whatsoever more shall be needful for the house of thy God, which thou shalt have occasion to bestow, bestow it out of the king's treasure house

and whosoever will not do the law of thy God and the law of the king of judgment be executed speedily upon him, whether it be unto death or to banishment or to confiscation of goods or to imprisonment
then I proclaimed a fast there at the river of Ahava that we might afflict ourselves before our God to seek of him a right way for us and for our little ones and for all our substance.
so we fasted and besought our God for this and he was entreated of us.
In this evening, if we look at Ezra in Ezra 8, we would have to conclude from his behavior that he believed God.

I referenced last week on Wednesday evening when we dealt with that subject of prayer and developing our attitude towards prayer, and we looked at a text of Scripture in Ezra chapter number 8 where Ezra was ashamed to ask for a group of soldiers to come and to help them along the way against the enemy.
